article.description: Connecticut's depth and defense quickly turned its Big East opener against St. John's into an 88-28 rout Tuesday night.
article.headline: Red Storm held to fewest points in school history

images.name: Williams_Tamika 120401 inline
images.caption: St. John's Creasie Fowler tries to slow the rout with some stellar defense on Tamika Williams.

article.linkText: UConn overwhelms St. John's by 60 points in Big East opener
article.story:
STORRS, Conn. (AP) -- Connecticut's depth and defense quickly turned its Big East opener against St. John's into an 88-28 rout Tuesday night.

<photo1>

The Huskies (8-0, 1-0 Big East) dominated wire-to-wire, jumping out to a 44-9 halftime lead and holding St. John's to the fewest points in school history.

"It's very hard to play in these kinds of game. You feel for the coaching staff on St. John's and you feel for the players," UConn coach Geno Auriemma said. "They have to come in here and play in this environment against our team. It's just not fair."

But such is life in the Big East conference, where UConn has dominated for more than a decade.

The Huskies have won 21 Big East titles, including 10 tournament championships. They shared the regular season title with eventual national champ Notre Dame last season.

"I don't believe in ties. I don't believe in sharing championships," Auriemma said. "I would like to think this particular group wants to win the Big East outright. And today was step one toward that."

Diana Taurasi scored 15 points to lead the Huskies. She also had three of UConn's eight blocks.

The overmatched Red Storm (2-6, 0-1) were down three starters
due to injuries, but coach Darcel Estep wasn't about to make
excuses.

"We may not have the most talented team on the floor, but fundamental basketball is fundamental basketball," Estep said. "And the mistakes we made in this type of game you can break down into mental mistakes."

UConn scored 32 points off 24 St. John's turnovers. The Huskies
had 14 steals. The Red Storm's previous low in scoring was 29,
against Louisiana Tech in 1995.

Taurasi hit two 3-pointers in UConn's opening 12-0 run. Midway through the first half the Huskies stretched the lead to 21-6 and began rotating in reserves.

The Red Storm were unable to make up any ground against the
UConn substitutes and trailed by 35 at the half. Rasheedah Brown
had all but one of St. John's first-half points as the Red Storm
shot just 3-of-20 from the floor in the period.

The second half was not any different. The Huskies outscored the
Red Storm 23-5 in the first 10 minutes of the half. By then all but
one UConn starter had been pulled. The Huskies shot 67 percent in
the second half and 63 percent for the game.

"You always want it to be a good game, but if it turns out to be a game like tonight, you just play and try to have fun and try to execute the things we worked on practice," Taurasi said.

UConn outrebounded the Red Storm 40-15 and outscored them 48-6 in the paint. The Huskies' reserves poured in 33 points.

Taurasi had three of UConn's eight blocks. Teammates Tamika
Williams finished with 12 points and Swin Cash had a game-high nine
rebounds.

Brown led St. John's with 11 points.

The Huskies have beaten St. John's 17 straight games, the
longest win streak over any UConn opponent.

UConn was coming off a 103-69 win over Ball State, a game the Huskies trailed for several minutes in the first half. Ball State hit 13 3-pointers, many of them uncontested, to keep the game close for a while. The Huskies weren't about to let it happen again.

   "Whenever we don't meet the standards that we set for ourselves we go to practice and we harp on it. And we usually come back and have a great effort," he said. "And tonight was a perfect example of that."
